p: The galectins constitute a family of soluble, primarily mammalian, C-type lectins that are produced by various tissues, including airway epithelium and immune cells [ 148]. They are typically between 14 and 35 kDa and contain a conserved CRD of about 130 amino acids that exclusively bind β-galactosides (such as lactose [Galβ(1–4)Glc] and N-acetyllactosamine [Galβ(1–4)GlcNAc]) [ 148] of influenza virus HA. Currently, 15 galectins have been identified in mammals, although only galectins -1 through -10, -12 and -13 (Gal -1 – Gal-10, Gal-12, and Gal-13) are found in humans [ 149]. They have a wide range of functions including mediation of cell–cell interactions, cell–matrix adhesion, and transmembrane signaling.
